Writing.title: Interface notes focused on reading flow.
Writing.description: Process notes on restrained motion, visual rhythm, and clarity-first interaction patterns.

articles.title: Rhythm Before Decoration
articles.summary: Subtle delays and tiny movement can guide attention better than louder visual effects.
articles.intro: Motion is only useful when it protects reading flow. Once animation starts competing with paragraph rhythm, the content loses priority.

sections.title: Keep motion measurable
paragraphs: Micro-interactions work best when they are barely above perception threshold. A one-pixel lift can feel intentional without becoming ornamental.
Delayed icon motion is effective because it reinforces hierarchy. Text stabilizes first, then the icon confirms intent a fraction later.
A calm hover system should improve scan speed. If users remember the animation more than the label, the balance is wrong.
Treat every transition as a reading aid. It should clarify what changed, not advertise itself.

sections.title: Guide attention with one anchor
paragraphs: Long pages need orientation, but they do not need decoration running through the full viewport.
A compact progress hint plus one high-contrast paragraph dot gives enough wayfinding for dense text.
IntersectionObserver is a practical trigger. It keeps activation logic stable while avoiding heavyweight scroll handlers.
When the active marker moves, interpolation should stay mild. The goal is continuity, not a dramatic chase effect.

sections.title: Design for reduced motion first
paragraphs: Reduced motion is not a degraded experience. It is a different contract where state changes remain clear without animated travel.
Direct positioning can still communicate progress and active context, as long as contrast and spacing are reliable.
Keyboard users should get the same clarity as pointer users. Focus rings and semantic order remain the primary interaction language.
A crafted interface is one that remains legible under every preference mode.

articles.title: Toolbox Entries as Interface Handbook
articles.summary: Utility cards should read like concise manual entries: what it is, what it does, and what to do next.
articles.intro: A practical toolbox does not need loud visuals. It needs predictable structure and quick scan cues that reduce decision time.

sections.title: Write cards for scanning
paragraphs: Each card should answer three questions immediately: what tool this is, what outcome it provides, and where the interaction starts.
A compact icon, short title, and single-line summary produce a reliable rhythm across tools.
Secondary guidance can be lightweight. A small uppercase hint works better than additional button clutter.
Consistency matters more than novelty. Repeated structure reduces cognitive load on return visits.

sections.title: Use one accent language
paragraphs: Accents should indicate action priority, not decorate every surface.
Border highlight, faint surface sheen, and tiny elevation shifts are usually enough to signal interactivity.
When every element glows, none of them guide. Keep high-contrast states reserved for active selection and focus.
The same motion token set should drive cards, buttons, and nav so the interface feels coherent.

sections.title: Preserve maintainability
paragraphs: Interaction polish should live in reusable primitives. Copy-pasting custom hover logic into pages makes drift inevitable.
Tokens for duration, easing, and delays keep craft consistent while still allowing local nuance.
Performance constraints are part of design quality. Avoid animations that force layout or repaint large regions.
The best toolbox UI is quiet, fast, and clear enough that users focus on work, not chrome.

ReadingDemo.title: Scroll-aware guidance with progress and paragraph focus.
ReadingDemo.intro: This page demonstrates a compact reading guide: a short progress meter plus a high-contrast dot that moves to the active paragraph start.

sections.title: Why this pattern
paragraphs: A long page can feel directionless when every paragraph has equal visual weight. A small progress indicator gives orientation without competing with content.
The guide dot is deliberately minimal. It marks where attention can return after a scroll jump, especially on dense writing pages.
The layout avoids a full-height decorative line. Instead, progress is contained in a short capsule so the interface stays quiet.
In practice, this pattern works best when typography is comfortable and spacing between paragraphs remains consistent.

sections.title: Interaction details
paragraphs: Section activation is driven by IntersectionObserver. Paragraphs become candidates when they enter a focused window in the viewport.
When several paragraphs overlap, scoring prefers the one closest to a reading focus line near the upper part of the screen.
Scroll updates are batched with requestAnimationFrame so progress remains smooth without heavy per-event work.
The guide dot uses small movement and clear contrast, which keeps the signal useful but subtle.

sections.title: Accessibility and fallback
paragraphs: With reduced motion enabled, animated following is disabled. The system still reports progress and updates guidance without motion effects.
The reading guide is decorative and marked as aria-hidden so keyboard and screen-reader navigation stay clean.
The component is route-agnostic and works in both locale prefixes, as long as anchors are marked with data-reading-anchor.
This keeps the implementation maintainable while preserving a polished reading experience.
